‚öì How $ETH  Plans to Survive Without Core Developers   Vitalik Buterin just outlined a 7-step plan to make Ethereum permanent. The goal is radical: design the network so it can function correctly even if every core developer disappeared tomorrow.   üè¶ The 7 Pillars of Survival are:   Quantum Resilience: Immediate 100-year cryptographic security.  ZK-Scaling: Mass adoption through ZK-EVM and PeerDAS.  Governance: Transitioning to a self-sustaining, "ossified" system.  Account Abstraction: Fully programmable user accounts.  Sustainable PoS: Long-term, decentralized staking stability.  DoS-Protection: A fee structure immune to spam attacks.  Censorship Resistance: Unstoppable block production.   Vitalik compares $ETH  to a hammer: a tool that works regardless of whether its manufacturer still exists. This reframes Ethereum from a tech startup into civilizational infrastructure.   #ETHBlockchain   #ETH  #ETHFoundation

Vitalik on World of Warcraft and His Path to Decentralization

On June 28, Ethereum founder Vitalik Buterin responded in an interview on the Vatnik Soup channel to claims that his dislike for centralized systems stemmed from World of Warcraft. He acknowledged being very upset when Blizzard weakened his warlock's abilities, but clarified that attributing his research into decentralization solely to this incident was an overstatement and partly humorous. Buterin also shared how he first learned programming and highlighted that both creating his own games and playing World of Warcraft significantly shaped his development.

Transaction monitoring struggles with multichain.

A price update originates on Ethereum. It propagates to Base. A redemption settles on Avalanche.

Without one single view, you're stitching explorers and calling engineers.

This is an infrastructure gap. üßµ
Single-chain explorers show raw events per network.

They don't reconstruct what actually happened: Intent ‚Üí Route ‚Üí State.

Centrifugescan was built to solve this. You need to see: what was supposed to happen, which path it took, whether it completed everywhere.
Contract-aware monitoring asks: Did the function execute?

Asset-aware monitoring asks: Did the redemption actually settle across all venues?

Infrastructure that stops at execution stops too early.
Monitoring is part of running the product.

A tokenized index updates NAV across three chains simultaneously. Each update cascades: collateral shifts, secondary pricing adjusts, compliance records flow.

Remove monitoring? The product becomes inoperable.
Infrastructure for multichain products:

Sees across all venues, reconstructs intent through execution, and  surfaces failures in product terms.

The U.S. Market Structure Bill and the Next Phase of Crypto ‚Äî On-Chain Data Signals Early Institutional Positioning via @cryptoquant_com (Analysis Report No. 178)

A draft U.S. Senate bill outlining a market structure framework for crypto assets has been released. While Bitcoin prices reacted positively in the short term, the real significance of this bill lies in its structural implications rather than immediate price movements.

The bill seeks to clearly distinguish crypto assets as either commodities or securities and define which regulatory authorities oversee each category. Until now, regulatory ambiguity has largely been addressed through enforcement actions, leaving market participants uncertain. This draft aims to reduce that uncertainty by clarifying classification criteria in advance.

Notably, fully decentralized networks and DeFi protocols are not treated as traditional financial intermediaries. Developers, validators, and node operators are not automatically classified as regulated entities, reflecting an acknowledgment of decentralization as a core structural feature. In contrast, centralized exchanges, brokers, and custodians face clearer requirements on registration, asset segregation, and disclosure‚Äîdesigned to support sustainable operations rather than suppress innovation. Bitcoin, Ethereum, stablecoins, and spot ETFs are all assumed to remain part of the U.S. financial system.

On-chain data already reflects this transition. CryptoQuant‚Äôs Spot Average Order Size shows that around the $90,000 level, retail participation remains limited, while mid- to large-sized orders are relatively prominent. This suggests neither speculative retail euphoria nor panic selling, but a phase in which large investors cautiously adjust positions while awaiting regulatory clarity.

Clear U.S. market structure rules are likely to influence institutional behavior and global regulatory discussions. While this bill is not a short-term price catalyst, on-chain indicators suggest the crypto market is already shifting from headline-driven moves toward a structure-driven phase.

Let me ask you a question, do you think Ethereum will peak below the last high around $5,000, or will it move higher? Tough question right?

Can we ask the chart and market?

Let's do some speculative technical analysis.

Bitcoin, Ethereum and a group of the big projects tend to move together, it tends to happen. As the market evolves, we are seeing how easily things change.

Bitcoin went on to produce a very strong all-time high compared to 2021, twice as high. Just to recap, back in 2021 Bitcoin peaked around $69,000. Bitcoin went on to produce a new all-time high in 2024 and then again in 2025 with a maximum price of $126,000. Ethereum didn't follow.

Ethereum peaked 2021 around $4,800 and recently, August 2025, Ethereum reached $4,957, a technical double-top. This is our context. Bitcoin did awesome. Ethereum also did good but not great.

Ethereum is now moving daily above EMA55. This signal, once confirmed, opens up bullish momentum for 1-3 months‚Äîmid-term. Seeing the lack of a new all-time high in 2024, and how we got a shy all-time high in 2025, it is possible to see Ethereum break beyond this barrier.

Ethereum challenged the $4,800 - $5,000 resistance zone twice already. Right now we have a very strong higher low compared to the start of the current move in April 2025. The drop from August to November was also a mild one when comparing to a full blown bear market as in 2022. So there is a strong possibility that the last resistance will not hold.

If we think about Bitcoin and say, "But, Bitcoin is likely to produce a lower high. How can Ethereum produce a higher high while Bitcoin produces a lower high?"

It is possible just as it happened in reverse. Bitcoin moved to hit a new all-time high while Ethereum was trading within the 2021 ATH range. This dynamic can alternate. Say, while Bitcoin is weak.

If this contract had gone live, someone would have figured out how to drain rewards, take control, or both.

We're sharing a short case study of a Vault Staking Rewards contract that was run through the in-depth Smart Contract Auditor inside AI Hub V2 before deployment.

On paper, the contract's setup was normal.

Multi pool staking, configurable reward rates, bonus distributions, emergency withdrawals, even a small on chain lottery. Nothing obviously dangerous.

Instead of relying on a quick scan, the team ran the contract through AI Hub V2‚Äôs in depth audit mode, built to surface real world failure paths, not just surface level issues.

The in depth audit flagged 12 issues, including 3 critical vulnerabilities that could have led to full protocol compromise if deployed as is.

One example was simple but dangerous.

A core function that controlled reward rates had no access control. Anyone could change emissions, either draining the reward pool or shutting rewards off completely.

Another issue involved ownership checks using tx.origin. That pattern makes phishing style takeovers possible with a single bad transaction.

The most serious finding was arbitrary delegatecall execution. An authorized address could run any logic in the contract‚Äôs context. If that address was compromised, ownership, funds, and internal state were all at risk.

The auditor also uncovered multiple reentrancy paths, including ETH withdrawals and reward claims where value was transferred before state was updated. Under the right conditions, this could allow repeated withdrawals or duplicated rewards.

None of these issues were obvious at first glance.
They only appeared when the contract was treated as something that could be attacked, not just something that compiles.

That is the value of an in depth audit inside AI Hub V2.

It shows you how a contract can fail before users ever touch it.
